Political compass (aka spectrum, square) is a system of coordinates on which various political movements can be distributed depending on the attitude to personal and economic freedom of a person. \n \n The quiz shows where you are in this system.

For the Ukrainian and Russian languages, several politicalcompass.org questions were adapted to the realities of the post-Soviet countries. Descriptions for ideologies were taken from wikipedia.org and other open sources.
Thanks to VoxUkraine (Maxim Skubenko), politicalcompass.org (David Wayne) and Timofey Brik for the resources and information support provided.

The quiz does not accurately determine your worldview, but shows your general way of thinking, your personal attitude to certain things in the economy and society. So if your result is "Socialism", this does not mean that you are a 100% socialist.
Horizontal axis: \n Economically Right / Economically Left

In the test, the Left-Right Axis measures economic views. \n "Left" supports government intervention and economic regulation, while the Right supports economic freedom and non-intervention. This means that the “Left” is inclined to support the efforts of the state to limit the which, in his opinion, is unfair or immoral phenomena of the free market, while "Right" is inclined to believe that transactions between private parties should mainly concluded without government intervention.

All liberals come from the belief that upholding individual freedoms is more important, than meeting the needs of society. Left-wing liberals tend to believe that a person cannot use his freedoms without a certain level of education and material comfort. In their view, this makes redistribution between rich and poor necessary. On the contrary, the Right Liberals tend to believe that taxing a person against his will for providing social benefits to others is an act of violence and, thus, violates individual freedom. They support charity and help for the poor, provided that they are voluntary. 
 
 All supporters of a more authoritarian type of government come from that the welfare of society is above the desires of specific individuals. Right-wing authoritarian hold so-called paternalistic political views. They defend a hierarchical society and take a tough stance against threats, - criminals are in prison, and foreign states are held back by strong defense.

Authoritarianism (authoritarian regime) - the concentration of power within the same group of like-minded people or in the hands of one person. Any serious opposition to the government is impossible or is decorative. 
 Under left-wing authoritarianism, private property is prohibited. 
 
 Signs of authoritarianism: 
 1. Alienation of the people from power 
 2. Centralization of power in the management of society by a certain person or group of people: 
 3. The leadership and management of society in all spheres of life is carried out mainly by command-administrative, command methods 
 4. Dominance in the political system of one, ruling party 
 5. The legal nature of the activities of the authorities is largely 
 6. Infringement of the rights and freedoms of citizens 
 7. The army, police, security agencies are used to suppress opposition forces, Opposing the regime, serve as an instrument and the main pillar of power. 
 
 All media and their content are taken under strict state control

Power-centrism is the belief that the state should intervene in society and to control its economic and social aspects. Considering the state as the highest result and goal of social development (the state is better than the individual). \n \n In economics, it leads to state monopoly.

Социализм - общественная система, при которой государство в значительной степени контролирует экономику и средства производства, а своей целью провозглашает равенство и справедливое распределение благ. 
 
 Социал-демократизм - тот же социализм, с контрольем экономики государством, но с политической свободой. 
 Не настаивают на необходимости принуждению национализации способов производства.

Socialism is a social system in which the state largely controls the economy. and means of production, and with its goal proclaims equality and equitable distribution of goods. 
 
 Socialism is characteristic: 
 • Great influence and state control over the economy 
 • Planned economy 
 • Nationalization of production, banking, transport systems (state-owner) 
 • Free medicine and education 
 • Large allowances and assistance to the poor 
 • Large taxes 
 \ n Core principles and values: 
 Equality, lack of exploitation, equitable distribution and public ownership. 
 
 The role of the state in economic life 
 The state regulates economic life, allocates resources, and limits private property. 
 
 Relation to social issues: 
 All people should have equal rights and obligations, the state is struggling with income inequality. 
 
 Ways to solve social issues: 
 State control, ensuring social equality.

Capitalism - economic freedom from government intervention, private property, legal equality and freedom of enterprise. The main criterion for making economic decisions is the desire to increase capital, to make a profit. \ n \ n With a radical version of Capitalism, there can be strong class inequality, exploitation of labor (child labor, a 16-hour working day, etc.), an oligarchy.

Conservatism advocates the preservation and strengthening of traditional public institutions - the state, churches, families, private property. Conservatives, unlike socialists, recognize social inequality as natural and oppose active government intervention in the economy. 
 
 Core principles and values: 
 Traditional institutions: state, family, church, private property. 
 The role of the state in economic life: 
 The state protects private property as the basis of the economy. 
 Relation to social issues: 
 People are not equal, some of them may have privileges. 
 Ways to solve social issues: 
 Strengthening the traditional foundations and institutions of society.

Progressivism is the support or promotion of social progress in society through reform, often opposed to conservatism, traditionalism and obscurantism. Like a philosophy it is based on the idea of ​​progress, which claims that advances in science, technology, economic development and social organization are vital to improving the human condition.

(aka anarcho-capitalism) 
 
 Anarchists advocate human freedom and deny the need for forced control 
 and man’s power over man. 
 
 Anarchists advocate the elimination of statehood and self-government, 
 that is, for a system of independent meetings of citizens who independently manage their life 
 and labor in the workplace, in the area of ​​residence, etc. 
 
 Right-wing anarchism is based on the conviction of the need for free possession private property, denial of any form of government or [its] interference, and supporting a competitive free market as the main mechanism for social interaction. ” Welcome the existence of private property, which was acquired through labor, trade or was received as a gift. 
 
 In this sense, the term right-wing anarchism (anarcho-capitalism) is often a synonym for "libertarianism."

Anarchists advocate human freedom and deny the need for forced 
 management and power of man over man. 
 
 Anarchists advocate self-government, that is, a system of independent assembly of citizens, 
 independently managing their life and work at the workplace, in the area of ​​residence, etc. 
 
 Anarchist society is a voluntary confederation of such assemblies. 
 
 The basic principles of anarchism 
 Core principles and values: 
 The lack of power of some people over others, freedom from coercion 
 The role of the state in economic life: 
 The state is not needed, it should not interfere in the economy: 
 Relation to social issues: 
 Refusal of private property will ensure equality of people 
 Ways to solve social issues: 
 In the absence of a state, people themselves will solve their problems

Liberalism proclaims the rights and freedom of every person as the highest value and establishes them as the legal basis of public and economic order. 
 Liberalism in general - the desire for freedom of the human spirit from constraint, imposed by state, religion, tradition, etc. 
 
 The most important freedoms in modern liberalism are the freedom to speak out publicly, freedom of choice of religion, freedom to choose representatives in fair and free elections 
 
 Core principles and values: 
 Freedom of personality, human rights, private property, democracy 
 
 The role of the state in economic life: 
 The state minimally intervenes in the free market, does not interfere with competition. 
 
 Relation to social issues: 
 People are equal before the law, otherwise the inequality is normal 
 
 Ways to solve social issues: 
 Reforms, gradual changes in society.

Maximum freedom of the economy and the individual. Maximum personality autonomy. Libertarians believe that a person has full rights (sovereignty) to his body, own life and property obtained as a result of her own efforts or voluntary exchange 

What libertarians want to undo: 
 • Taxes (or at least drastically reduce the amount and reduce the remaining, because, from their point of view, this is legalized robbery by the state) 
 • Conscription 
 • Punishment for crimes without a victim (e.g. drug use, prostitution, arms smuggling, driving in a seat belt) 
 • Antitrust bans 
 What libertarians want to legitimize 
 • Same-sex marriage 
 • Free carrying weapons 
 • Euthanasia 
 What libertarians argue about 
 • Legalization of all types of immigration 
 • Abortion - part of the libertarians believe that from an early period of development, the fetus has the same rights, as a born person; their opponents believe the abortion ban violates the mother’s right to choose 
 • Age of sexual consent - some libertarians believe that it should be abolished altogether, 
 since it is introduced arbitrarily by the authorities and, accordingly, can be considered violent. 
 • Deprivation of rights due to incapacitation - some libertarians believe that this is also an “attack” on personal autonomy 
 • International politics - some libertarians reject the right of countries to intervene; another thinks 
 that they are possible if basic human rights are systematically violated somewhere 
 
 They advocate the so-called minimum state, or a state that acts as a “night watchman”. Its functions should be reduced to ensuring national defense, law and order and judicial procedures. 
 Unlike libertarianism, supporters of anarchism against any hierarchies and power, demand the complete elimination of the state.

(aka anarcho-communism) 
 
 Anarchists advocate human freedom and deny the need for forced management and power of man over man. 
 
 Anarchists advocate the elimination of statehood and self-government, that is, for a system of independent meetings of citizens who independently manage their lives and labor in the workplace, in the area of ​​residence, etc. 
 
 Under left-wing anarchism, money will have to cease to exist, people will not receive direct compensation for labor (through the separation of profits and wages), but will have to have free access to all resources and surpluses produced by the commune. That is, instead of private, there will be collective, public property.

(closer to anarcho-communism) 
 
 In socialism, the state largely controls the economy and means production, and its goal proclaims equality and fair distribution of goods. 
 
 But libertarian socialists advocate the abolition of private property on the means of production and the state as an unnecessary and harmful institution. They are anti-capitalists and opponents of a market economy. In the end most Marxists agree with this, but for libertarian socialists anti-authoritarianism and anti-parliamentarism.
